analytic.title: A Novel Scheme for Key Performance Indicator Prediction and Diagnosis With Application to an Industrial Hot Strip Mill

div.p: In this paper, a data-driven scheme of key performance indicator (KPI) prediction and diagnosis is developed for complex industrial processes. For static processes, a KPI prediction and diagnosis approach is proposed in order to improve the prediction performance. In comparison with the standard partial least squares (PLS) method, the alternative approach significantly simplifies the computation procedure. By means of a data-driven realization of the so-called left coprime factorization (LCF) of a process, efficient KPI prediction, and diagnosis algorithms are developed for dynamic processes, respectively, with and without measurable KPIs. The proposed KPI prediction and diagnosis scheme is finally applied to an industrial hot strip mill, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.
Index Terms-Data-driven, hot strip mill, key performance indicator (KPI), prediction and diagnosis.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T O meet increasing demands for high production and product quality as well as economic operation, today's industrial processes have become more complex and their automation degree is significantly growing. Associated with this trend, issues like process monitoring and diagnosis receive enhanced attention, both in engineering and research domains, and they are often addressed either by the model-based process monitoring and diagnosis techniques [1], [2], observer schemes [3], [4], or by the data-driven techniques [5]- [7]. These techniques mainly serve monitoring of process variables and, based on it, detecting and identifying those faults in sensors, actuators, or process components. In comparison, the application of data-driven methods, thanks to their simple forms and Manuscript

fewer requirements on the design and engineering efforts, is more popular in many industry sectors, while the model-based methods are mainly applied to automatic control systems with well-established process models.

In a complex industrial system, the technical production process often consists of numerous control loops with a huge number of sensors and actuators embedded in the loops. Since production and product quality are in general not online measurable or the measurement is only realizable after the production process is completed, efficient quality prediction and diagnosis play an important role in complex industrial systems. For this purpose, the concept of key performance indicator (KPI) has been introduced and the KPI-based quality prediction and diagnosis cover a wide range of requirements from industrial applications [8]- [13]. For instance, for a hot strip mill process in the steel manufacturing industry, engineers are highly interested in the relationship between operating conditions and those KPIs of the final product like thickness or flatness. Although much effort has been devoted to developing the analytical model of the hot strip mill process, performing a reliable KPI prediction is still a challenging issue in practice due to the process complexity. Generally speaking, it is the state of the art that the product quality prediction is performed by skilled operators based on their experiences, which, however, also causes potential threats to reliability and safety of the considered plants. Therefore, the KPI prediction based on the available measurements of process variables is highly necessary in practice and becomes a critical factor for the quality control. Moreover, in order to ensure the successful operation of such complex process, it is necessary to detect those process faults as early as possible, which will otherwise significantly affect the product quality.

It is the objective of this work to study KPI prediction and diagnosis and their application to a hot strip mill process in the steel manufacturing industry. To this end, we have decided, based on our experiences in monitoring and control of hot strip mill processes, to apply data-driven techniques.

The most popular data-driven methods to achieve fault-diagnosis tasks are principle component analysis (PCA) [14], [15] and partial least squares (PLS) [16], which are proposed in the multivariate statistical framework and become dominant datadriven tools for complex industrial processes [17]. In particular, PLS is widely accepted in industry as a KPI prediction method with superior ability in processing a huge amount of highly correlated process data. The original idea behind the PLS is to identify the correlation model between the measured process variables and KPI and, based on it, to predict KPI using online observations of process variables. For diagnosis purposes, a PLS-related approach aims to detect the faults in process variables that are mostly related to the KPI. Although the PLS-based KPI prediction and diagnosis have been utilized in many applications, some deficits have been reported in [18] and [19]. Moreover, the performance of PLS relevant methods is limited in coping with the KPI prediction and diagnosis in (highly) dynamic industrial processes [20] and sophisticated extensions are needed [21], [22].

Motivated by these observations, we will address two topics in this paper: 1) developing an efficient data-driven KPI prediction and diagnosis scheme for static processes, which will offer an alternative solution to the PLS method, and 2) proposing a data-driven KPI prediction and diagnosis scheme for dynamic processes. Our major goal is to solve KPI prediction and diagnosis problems met in the hot strip mill process.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, an alternative solution to the PLS method is first introduced. It is followed by the study on the data-driven design of dynamic KPI prediction and diagnosis. Section III is dedicated to the application to an industrial hot strip mill process. The process description, industry requirements, as well as process abnormalities will be presented in detail. The proposed data-driven approaches are implemented on the hot strip mill process, and the achieved results are discussed in Section IV.

div.head: II. KPI PREDICTION AND DIAGNOSIS
div.p: This section is devoted to the development of a KPI computation and prediction scheme, which includes two algorithms, respectively, for static and dynamic processes.

div.head: B. KPI Prediction and Diagnosis Approach for Dynamic Processes
div.p: Although rarely emphasized in publications, data normalization described in (1) and ( 2), both in the training and online monitoring phases, plays an important role in the PLS, dynamic PLS (DPLS) methods, and in the approach proposed above. It is evident that such a normalization can only be successfully realized under the stationary operating condition. The key step of all approaches is the normalization procedure, in which the process variables are mean centered and often variance-scaled to further construct the residual signals and test statistics. In real applications, we often meet situations that the process under consideration is in dynamic operations. In this case, the performance of those normalization procedure of PLS-related methods is limited. On the other hand, it is known that the main advantage of the model-based techniques [2] lies in their ability to deal with dynamic process monitoring and diagnosis. It is similar to normalization procedure in PLS-related approaches but the residual signal is constructed by utilizing analytical process model to remove deterministic influence in the considered process variable. A successful application of the model-based techniques requires a sophisticated modeling procedure, which is often not realizable and a handicap especially for applications in complex industrial processes. Motivated by these observations, we propose next a data-driven method for the KPI prediction and fault detection.

div.head: III. APPLICATION IN INDUSTRIAL HOT STRIP MILL
div.p: Here, the above proposed KPI prediction and diagnosis scheme for static as well as dynamic processes are applied to a key process in the steel manufacturing industry: the hot strip mill.

div.head: A. Industrial Hot Strip Mill Description
div.p: As schematically described in Fig. 1, the industrial hot strip mill basically consists of six subprocesses in turn. The furnaces heat the steel slab up to approximately 1200 C, where the thickness is about 200 mm. Then the slab is rolled back and forth in the roughing mill to about 28-45 mm thick with output temperature around 1050 C. After transported through transfer table, the head and tail of the strip are sheared to prevent damaging the work rolls. The finishing mill has the most significant influence on the final thickness of steel strip, in which the controlled variables include average gap and total force of the 7 finishing mill stands and work roll bending (WRB) force of the last six stands (WRB force of the first stand is not measured). The thickness and temperature of the strip after finishing rolling are around 850 C-950 C and 1.5-12.7 mm, respectively. As is well known from materials science, the kinetics of metallurgical transformations and the flow stress of the rolled steel strip are dominantly controlled by the temperature, which is mainly determined by the coiling temperature control (CTC). Thus, the following subprocess, i.e., laminar cooling, plays a quite important role in steel production industry. At the end, the strips are coiled as intermediate or final products.

div.head: B. Implementation of KPI Prediction and Diagnosis Scheme
div.p: A four-step implementation procedure for KPI prediction and diagnosis scheme is depicted in Fig. 2. At first, KPIs should be defined according to specific process characteristics, economical benefits, and quality requirements. In the case of hot strip mill, strip thickness, temperature, and flatness can be defined as KPIs for instance. The next step is to select process variables which are responsible for the given KPIs. The realization of this step is mainly based on the process knowledge, but some data based methods also exist, e.g., causality analysis and transfer entropy. As an example for demonstrating the effectiveness of our novel methods, we define the finishing mill exit strip thickness as a KPI. According to our knowledge about the case process, 20 process variables are selected. Together with the KPI, the process variables are described in Table III. The offline training as well as the online prediction and diagnosis procedures have been realized as described in Section II for static and dynamic processes, respectively.

div.head: IV. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
div.p: As discussed so far, the first objective of our study is to predict KPI, i.e., thickness of the strip, only based on the process variables. The process variables listed in Table III are utilized to predict KPI in case of normal operation. The prediction performance of the static approach can be seen from Fig. 3, in which the predicted thickness shows relatively smooth variations around 3.95 mm, since dynamic property of the underlying process has not been taken into account.

On the other hand, the data-driven LCF-based dynamic approach is able to deal with dynamic processes, as shown in Figs. 4 and5. It is obvious from Fig. 4 that the dynamic prediction approach with unmeasurable KPI shows better performance than the static one. Since KPI measurements are used for Fig. 5, the predicted strip thickness are almost equal to the measurement, which is similar to the case with the application of a filter-or observer-based scheme.

The result of KPI based plant abnormality/performance degradation diagnosis for static processes is given in Fig. 6, the first (around) 100 samples belong to the transition phase, where the static model trained with normal precess data in steady state is not yet valid. This is why the overshoot of threshold does not indicate any fault scenario. As given in Fig. 9, from the 1001st sample, an additive fault happens in , i.e., the third stand's total force. Because of the complexity and closed-loop nature of real-life plants, the fault has propagated to other process are given in Figs. 678. We can see that all three methods have delivered successful fault-detection results. Nevertheless, the approaches for dynamic processes give more useful information for fault diagnosis in the sense of early detection. We can also see that both dynamic approaches have detected the fault with less time delay than the static one. Since KPI measurements are utilized for Fig. 8, the diagnosis performance in sense of detection time and fault sensitivity is better than the dynamic approach without KPI measurements. (Remark: the overshoots during the starting phase in Figs. 7 and8 are mainly caused by initial state uncertainty of the LCF-based algorithm).

We would like to remark that, regarding industrial implementation, it is generally not wise to claim that the dynamic approach is superior to the static one or with the order reversed. Selection of prediction and diagnosis method should be dependent of the underlying process nature (e.g., how significant/fast is the dynamic), computation limitation, memory cost, economic benefits, robustness requirements, and design complexity.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have presented a data-driven scheme for KPI prediction and diagnosis for complex industrial processes. Compared with standard static approaches, e.g., PLS, the proposed approach can improve the prediction performance and significantly simplify the needed computation steps involved in diagnosis, as discussed in Section II. For dynamic processes, the well-known LCF technique has been realized in a data-driven fashion, based on which efficient KPI prediction and diagnosis algorithms have been developed with measurable and unmeasurable KPIs, respectively. The industrial implementation issues of the proposed KPI prediction and diagnosis scheme have been discussed in Section III. With a successful application to an industrial hot strip mill process, the effectiveness and issues have been discussed in Section IV.
